src_text.0: Τὰν ἅλα τὰν γλαυκὰν ὅταν ὥνεμος ἀτρέμα βάλλῃ, τὰν φρένα τὰν δειλὰν ἐρεθίζομαι, οὐδ’ ἔτι μοι γᾶ ἐστὶ φίλα, ποθίει δὲ πολὺ πλέον ἁ μεγάλα μ’ ἅλς.
src_text.1: ἀλλ’ ὅταν ἀχήσῃ πολιὸς βυθός, ἁ δὲ θάλασσα κυρτὸν ἐπαφρίζῃ, τὰ δὲ κύματα μακρὰ μεμήνῃ, ἐς χθόνα παπταίνω καὶ δένδρεα, τὰν δ’ ἅλα φεύγω, γᾶ δέ μοι ἀσπαστά, χἀ δάσκιος εὔαδεν ὕλα, ἔνθα καὶ ἢν πνεύσῃ πολὺς ὥνεμος, ἁ πίτυς ᾅδει.
src_text.2: ἦ κακὸν ὁ γριπεὺς ζώει βίον, ᾧ δόμος ἁ ναῦς, καὶ πόνος ἐστὶ θάλασσα, καὶ ἰχθύες ἁ πλάνος ἄγρα.
src_text.3: αὐτὰρ ἐμοὶ γλυκὺς ὕπνος ὑπὸ πλατάνῳ βαθυφύλλῳ, καὶ παγᾶς φιλέοιμι τὸν ἐγγύθεν ἆχον ἀκούειν, ἃ τέρπει ψοφέοισα τὸν ἀγρικόν, οὐχὶ ταράσσει.
src_text.4: Ἤρατο Πὰν Ἀχῶς τᾶς γείτονος, ἤρατο δ’ Ἀχὼ σκιρτατᾶ Σατύρω, Σάτυρος δ’ ἐπεμήνατο Λύδᾳ.
src_text.5: ὡς Ἀχὼ τὸν Πᾶνα, τόσον Σάτυρος φλέγεν Ἀχώ, καὶ Λύδα Σατυρίσκον· Ἔρως δ’ ἐσμύχετ’ ἀμοιβᾷ.
src_text.6: ὅσσον γὰρ τήνων τις ἐμίσεε τὸν φιλέοντα, τόσσον ὁμῶς φιλέων ἠχθαίρετο, πάσχε δ’ ἃ ποίει.
src_text.7: ταῦτα λέγω πᾶσιν τὰ διδάγματα τοῖς ἀνεράστοις· στέργετε τὼς φιλέοντας, ἵν’ ἢν φιλέητε φιλῆσθε.
src_text.8: Ἀλφειὸς μετὰ Πῖσαν ἐπὴν κατὰ πόντον ὁδεύῃ, ἔρχεται εἰς Ἀρέθοισαν ἄγων κοτινηφόρον ὕδωρ, ἕδνα φέρων καλὰ φύλλα καὶ ἄνθεα καὶ κόνιν ἱράν, καὶ βαθὺς ἐμβαίνει τοῖς κύμασι, τὰν δὲ θάλασσαν νέρθεν ὑποτροχάει, κοὐ μίγνυται ὕδασιν ὕδωρ, ἁ δ’ οὐκ οἶδε θάλασσα διερχομένω ποταμοῖο.
src_text.9: κῶρος λινοθέτας κακομάχανος αἰνὰ διδάσκων καὶ ποταμὸν διὰ φίλτρον Ἔρως ἐδίδαξε κολυμβῆν.
src_text.10: Λαμπάδα θεὶς καὶ τόξα βοηλάτιν εἵλετο ῥάβδον οὖλος Ἔρως, πήρην δ’ εἶχε κατωμαδίην, καὶ ζεύξας ταλαεργὸν ὑπὸ ζυγὸν αὐχένα ταύρων ἔσπειρεν Δηοῦς αὔλακα πυροφόρον.
src_text.11: εἶπε δ’ ἄνω βλέψας αὐτῷ Διί· πλῆσον ἀρούρας, μή σε τὸν Εὐρώπης βοῦν ὑπ’ ἄροτρα βάλω.

tgt_text.0: FOR the biography of the foremost of Bucolic minstrels, the pastoral poet Theocritus, unfortunately few materials exist.
tgt_text.1: Indeed the little which is known is inferred either from the actual poems of Theocritus himself, or from such as have been published under his name.
tgt_text.2: Of the latter class is the 22nd epigram, from which we gather his parentage and birth-place, and which is generally held to have been the work of Ar­ temidorus the grammarian.
tgt_text.3: Evidently written with a view to distinguishing between our poet and his Chian namesake, an orator and sophist, it fixes for his native place Syracuse, and for his parents Praxagoras and Philinna.
tgt_text.4: With this account Suidas substantially agrees, though he adds that some make Theocritus the son of Simichus, or Simichidas, and holds that, being originally a native of Cos, he had become a metæch or foreign settler at Syracuse.
tgt_text.5: Now if we compare this notion with the Scholia on the 7th Idyll, vs. 21, (where it is suggested by some that the name is an assumed one, derived from σίμος, flat-nosed,) as well as with the Θεοκϱίτου γένος, it seems that a confusion has arisen with regard to the identity of Theocritus with Simichidas, into whose mouth the 7th Idyll is put.
tgt_text.6: It does not seem to have occurred to those who make Simi­ chus the father of the Syracusan poet, that bards are wont to shadow forth their own words, thoughts, and acts, under ficti­ tious names and unreal characters, and that Theocritus might really have described what happened to himself in the "Thaly­ sia," and yet not have used the name of Simichidas, otherwise than Virgil uses that of Tityrus.
tgt_text.7: —Nor is there any reason to suppose that the claims of Cos to the honour of his birth and early training rest on stronger grounds than that he studied under Philetus of Cos, whom he mentions in Idyll vii.
tgt_text.8: 40, whe­ ther at Cos itself or in Alexandria is not clear.
tgt_text.9: Of Philetus,. and Asclepiades, of whom he speaks as τὸν ἐσθλὸν Σικελίδαν το̃ν ἐκ Σάμω, (Idyll vii. 40,) it is known that they were dis­ tinguished poets of the Alexandrian school, whom Theocritus professedly admired, and of the former of whom he was pro­ bably a pupil.
tgt_text.10: There is internal evidence in the Idylls of the poet, that I resided for some space at Alexandria, and afterwards at Syracuse, whilst the 7th Idyll shows such a knowledge of the localities of Cos, as could hardly, one should think, have been obtained without a personal acquaintance with the island.
tgt_text.11: Here may have arisen his intimacy with Ni­ cias of Miletus, the physician to whom he dedicated the 11th and 13th Idylls, and to whose wife, Theugenis, he wrote a pleasing ditty, (28th,) with a silver distaff.
tgt_text.12: -But this is mere conjecture, arising probably out of the nearness of Cos to Miletus.
tgt_text.13: To Alexandria Theocritus was no doubt at­ tracted by the fame of its library, founded by Ptolemy Soter, and raised to its highest point of eminence by his son Philadelphus, under whose care it became the resort of tht, most distinguished literati of the day, Zenodotus, Callimachus, Hegesias, Euclid, Aratus.
tgt_text.14: To the last of these, the astro­ nomer and poet, who was the author of the Phænomena, he addressed his 6th Idyll, and his name occurs again in the Idyll following.
tgt_text.15: Association with such a man would not be without its advantages, and we here and there discover traces of his having imbibed from his friend some acquaintance with astronomical matters.
tgt_text.16: But it was probably at Alex­ andria, too, that he found access to the pages of the Septua­ gint, itself a lasting monument of the Egyptian monarch's zeal in the collection of literary treasures.
tgt_text.17: No one can read the 16th, 18th, 20th, and 23rd Idylls without being struck by the similarity of thought and expression of passages in each, to portions of the Psalms of David, the Book of Job, the Song of Solomon, and the Prophecies of Isaiah.
tgt_text.18: The parallels have been pointed out in the notes to the present translation:
tgt_text.19: but the strength of internal evidence to the supposition that Theo­ critus availed himself of the access, which he might undoubt­ edly have had, to the Septuagint, receives additional force in the comparison of the whole scene of altercation between Pollux and Amycus with the historical record of the encounter be­ tween David and Goliath in the First Book of Samuel.
tgt_text.20: It can hardly be doubted that Theocritus composed the 14th, 15th, and 17th Idylls at Alexandria :
tgt_text.21: he could not have enjoyed even the passing favour and brief notice of Ptolemy Phila­ delphus, without becoming interested in the law and records of that strange race, the Jews of many wanderings ;
tgt_text.22: one hun­ dred and twenty thousand of whom had been liberated by that monarch from the slavery in which Ptolemy Soter had bound them.
tgt_text.24: 2) writes at length respecting the interest shown by Ptolemy Philadelphus in obtaining for his vast library an accurate translation of the Books of the Old Testament.
tgt_text.25: We find from him how the monarch strove to purchase the good will of the nation by sending splendid gifts to the God of Israel:
tgt_text.26: how he valued the translators and their translations :
tgt_text.27: and how he conversed with his librarian, Demetrius Phalereus, on the deep meaning and superior wisdom of the Jewish law.
tgt_text.28: And we know enough of the tide of fashion, especially if it is royal taste that lifts the floodgate, which carries onward successful literature of any class, to feel sure that a scholar could hardly have tarried even for a brief space at Alexandria without inspect­ ing that volume, which even to heathens was a work of wonder, fostered by reflecting credit upon one of the fore­ most of the then rulers of the world.
tgt_text.29: A poet likewise, im­ bued, as was Theocritus, with a sense of the charm of natural simplicity, and having withal, as some of his poems show, no mean appreciation of the glorious epic, could never have been content with a transient glance at a collection of Such infinite graces, simplicity, grandeur, natural colouring, and noble imagery, as the translation of the Seventy elders, inferior though it be in diction to the original.
tgt_text.31: like others, he dipped often into that well of wisdom, albeit he knew not the spell which renders it sweeter to the taste than all other waters.
tgt_text.32: Hovering around those sacred pages, he caught the scent of flowers of poesy, which he has transferred into his Idylls, and we have the gratification of an involuntary testi­ nony from a heathen poet to the charms of composition and material, with which the sacred volume is so richly fraught.
tgt_text.33: Our taste will be wilfully dull, if it acknowledge not the extreme probability that the Syracusan saw the Septuagint, and there need be no stumbling-block in the argument that he no where mentions the Jews.
tgt_text.34: He dived for pearls of poesy, leaving unexplored the buried treasures of history and reli­ gion.
tgt_text.35: Without satisfactory data for any certain conclusion, we can at least give the benefit of probabilities in favour of our poet's acquaintance with the Septuagint.
tgt_text.36: From this we pass on to other matter.
tgt_text.37: Theocritus, while at Alexandria, was allowed, we presume, to dedicate his 17th Idyll to Ptolemy Philadelphus ;
tgt_text.38: and we have reason to suppose that the 14th and 15th were com­ posed there also.
tgt_text.39: But it is clear that he did not find the monarch and his capital such kindly fosterers of his Muse as he might have expected:
tgt_text.40: for very soon we find him hymning at Syracuse the praises (considerably qualified by doubts of his open-handedness) of King Hiero the Second.
tgt_text.41: That monarch had ascended the throne B. C. 270 :
tgt_text.42: and the Idyll to which reference has been made, appears to have been written during the 1st Punic War, if we may judge from the allusion which he makes to the failing Carthagi­ nians, and Hiero's alliance with their implacable foe.
tgt_text.43: This would fix the date of the Idyll as 263 B. c.;
tgt_text.44: when a treaty between Hiero and the Romans was concluded.
tgt_text.45: But the rays of courtly favour must have .
tgt_text.46: been here also any thing but warm, the atmosphere chilly, when a poet was to be cher­ ished, or creative genius to be saved from starvation and blight.
tgt_text.47: Hiero's munificence was bestowed rather on kingdoms and potentates, than on minstrels and their songs.
tgt_text.49: Theo­ critus discovered at this point the mistake of trusting in princes for the advancement of poetic excellence:
tgt_text.50: at any rate, the greater portion of his Idylls show him to have sought in the calm tranquillity of country life and pastoral scenery, that independent self-reliance, Which, after all, is the safest nurse of the lovely rhyme.
tgt_text.51: Though when he rises to heroics, as in the encomiums on Ptolemy and Hiero, and in the 22nd, 24th, and 25th Idylls, he fully sustains his reputation, and no where falls into poverty of language, or mediocrity of conception;
tgt_text.52: yet it is on the first eleven Idylls, the 14th, 15th, and 21st, that his title to the fame, which has been universally ac­ corded to him, is most really and justly based.
tgt_text.53: Bion and Moschu3 are pretty conceit-weavers :
tgt_text.54: they sometimes delight US'with passages unrivalled for warmth of colouring and ten­ derness of pathos :
tgt_text.55: -but for simple rural life, accurately and tastefully depicted, for the thorough appreciation of nature, and reliance thereupon for the staple of his song, Theocritus ranks immeasurably above them.
tgt_text.56: He stands alone, with a crowd of imitators at a wide interval of merit.
tgt_text.57: Virgil's Ec­ logues have no inherent stamp of reality about them.
tgt_text.58: We lack the shepherd's account of his own life among his sheep.
tgt_text.59: There is more of polish than of nature.
tgt_text.60: We have the cour­ tier drawing smooth pictures from fancy ;
tgt_text.61: not the passion­ ate lover of the country deriving his materials from the real landscapes on which he is actually looking out.
tgt_text.62: To borrow an apt expression, Virgil's Eclogues are pictures of a polished mind playing at shepherd.
tgt_text.63: And as to our own pastoral writers, Spenser, Pope, Gay, Lyttleton, and Shenstone, none reach to half the height of Bucolic minstrelsy, to which their great model undeniably attained.
tgt_text.64: Spenser's dialect and metre are unfavourable to his subject;
tgt_text.65: and hecan lay no claim to be a true bard of nature ;
tgt_text.66: while it is matter of fact that beneath his rural images there is an under-current of allusion to matters of religion.
tgt_text.67: Who can enjoy with true zest the pastoral, where the shepherd Roffin symbolizes a bishop of Rochester, and the watch-dog Lowder, one of his chaplains ?
tgt_text.69: And as for Pope, whose pretensions rank next, his pastorals deserve credit only because they were written by a boy of sixteen ;
tgt_text.70: it were an insult to compare them with the mature productions of Theocritus.
tgt_text.71: For smoothness of versification, they have indeed won praise from Macaulay and the Earl of Carlisle;
tgt_text.72: but these two most capable judges assign to them no higher meed.
tgt_text.73: Indeed, had Pope's pastorals alone survived their author, we may well question whether his name would have even been remembered.
tgt_text.74: As for the rest, they claim still less right to tread the same ground, to rank in the same order with Theocritus, in that portion of the temple of fame which good taste will always assign to the Pastoral or Bu­ colic poets.
tgt_text.75: Coarse though the Syracusan bard be here and there, he is indeed, as Quinctilian calls him, " admirabilis in suo genere," nor is it any detraction from his well-won laurels that the same critic goes on to say, " sed musa illa rustica et pastoralis non forum mode, verum ipsam etiam urbem reformidat."
tgt_text.77: It must be borne in mind, when we stumble on grave objections against the poems of Theocritus, that his idea of simplicity is not a transcendental, but a natural one.
tgt_text.78: He has no model Arcadia in view :
tgt_text.79: his eye is all the while upon the woods and vales and river pastures of his native Sicily ;
tgt_text.80: taking his shepherds as he found them there, mak­ in,, them speak what they did speak, not what they ought to have spoken.
tgt_text.81: There are blemishes to his Idylls, which cer­ tainly render an expurgated edition of them a desideratum :
tgt_text.82: but these affect more or less all the chief writers of antiquity.
tgt_text.83: The question however which is just now dividing the educa­ tional world of France, seems to us to admit of but one solu­ tion.
tgt_text.84: What is true of most of the Greek and Latin Classics, is of course true of Theocritus, as one of them.
tgt_text.85: We cannot) forego the charms of the whole, because our delicacy is of­ fended, our purity shocked, by one or two Idylls, which, while they illustrate the darkest traits in the life of a heathen, only make us the more thankful that Christianity has at least gone far to banish one of the worst forms of human guilt and degradation.)
tgt_text.86: But upon the whole, the poems of Theocritus, without aiming at any deep moral lesson, are eminently calcu­ lated to nourish in us a growth of that keen taste for rural scenery, which is one of the purest and finest of earthly yearn­ ings :
tgt_text.87: whilst in liveliness, variety, and rhythm they certainly surpass anything of their kind, ancient or modern.
tgt_text.88: And this must have arisen from the familiarity in which, we infer, The­ ocritus passed his latter years with rural scenes and characters.
tgt_text.89: It is seldom that we have no notice, at any rate no tradition, respecting the death of the poets of the ancient world.
tgt_text.90: Of Hesiod, Simonides, Æschylus, Sophocles, Callimachus, Apol­ lonius, Rhodius, (and these are but a few names taken hap-ha­ zard,) we find some story at least, vague though it be, of their death or their burial-place.
tgt_text.91: But Theocritus seems to have vanished from before the eyes of men, after he had lamented at Syracuse the small account in which bards of his day were held of tyrants.
tgt_text.92: May he not have ended his days unnoticed in some quiet spot, to rise long after into fame by his depic­ tion of it, while his bones lay sepulchred on one of the head­ lands which he puts before us so vividly ?

tgt_text.98: In a note upon this passage in the Delphin edition, it is ob­ served, that the old interpreters understood this to mean that Theocritus was hung by the son of Hiero, king of Sicily, on account of his invectives against him.
tgt_text.99: But this only proves the fear of him, who wrote the epigram before alluded to, as distinguishing the name-sakes of Syracuse and Chios, to have been a well-grounded fear.
tgt_text.100: Ovid, if, by the Syracusan poet, he means Theocritus, seems to have stumbled on the rock of which that epigram might have warned him.
tgt_text.101: The fate of the Chian seems to have been transferred in his mind to the Syracusan, as will be seen by the following extract from Macrobius, Saturnalia, lib. vii. c. 3."King Antigonus put to death the Chian Theocritus, al­ though he was bound by an oath to spare him, on account of an unfortunate joke of that individual at his expense.
tgt_text.102: For when he was being dragged before Antigonus as if to receive punishment, and his friends were comforting him, and afford­ ing hopes that he would experience the royal clemency, when once he had come before the eyes of the king ;
tgt_text.103: Then,' observed he, ‘ the hope you hold out of safety is a vain one.'
tgt_text.104: For the king had lost one eye.
tgt_text.105: So the ill-timed witticism cost the prisoner his life.
tgt_text.106: "Now if we thus clear away this very apparent confusion between the two, we have no account of the death of the pastoral poet;
tgt_text.107: no, nor the vaguest allusion to it.
tgt_text.108: But the works which survive him are evidence that he has not all died:
tgt_text.109: while taste survives, he must hold undisputed supremacy in his own branch of the poetic art.
tgt_text.110: Of the origin and nature of that species of poetry which dates its ascendency from Theocritus, there is little which has not been said again and again.
tgt_text.111: The student who desires to arrive at the results of older lucubrations on this subject, must wade through subtle distinctions and learned disquisitions respecting pastoral and heroic poetry.
tgt_text.112: He will find that the birth-place of the former is contended by some to have been Sicily, by others Arcadia.
tgt_text.113: And while one and another ascribe its first authorship to various poets of more or less historical periods, some have been fain to date it from the golden age.
tgt_text.114: Now, when we gain experience of the diffi­ culties which arise in reconciling so many and diverse state­ ments, and find that the more effort we make, the further we drift into a sea of troubles, our natural inclination coincides with some sort of likelihood, which is in favour of that last opinion.
tgt_text.115: The truth may be that some kind of pastoral was the first form of poetry.
tgt_text.116: What more natural, when we reflect that the eldest of the human race reckoned their superiority by their flocks and herds.
tgt_text.118: and so little of shame was there connected with an occupation now so lowly, that no higher or more expressive title for a mighty ruler was sought than that of " shepherd of his peoples."
tgt_text.119: Of course, under these circumstances, the pastoral was likely to be an early form of poetry, and withal one not likely to be despised.
tgt_text.120: Indeed, among those who practised it at an early date were Moses and Miriam, Deborah and Barak, as well as the sweet Psalmist of Israel.
tgt_text.121: When therefore we discuss the age of its invention, we can but say that it was of every age.
tgt_text.122: The first up-rising of it was, we may conclude, in that primæval condition of men, when the system of concentration into towns and fenced cities had not yet begun:
tgt_text.123: but when men led a nomad life, and whiled their hours afield by alternate strains, whilst they were pastur­ ing their flocks.
tgt_text.124: It was the song of nature, little polished per­ haps, but still not without its inspiration, because it flowed directly from the shrines of her, whom he that worships most is ever the truest and most accepted poet.
tgt_text.125: The rustling of the trees, the vocal pine, the murmurings of rivulets, the very notes of birds, were so many of nature's hints to man to create for himself a harmony more excellent in proportion as the gift of speech excels all inarticulate sounds.
tgt_text.126: And when we add to this the influence of a sunny sky, a genial atmosphere, a mind unruffled with the cares and sins which harass and pollute the life of crowded cities, the wonder would be if song had not arisen ;
tgt_text.127: and that song, in common gratitude, of such a kind as should depict and hold up to imitation the life which was so singularly blessed.
tgt_text.128: Gratitude, too, led them no doubt to celebrate the festivals of their gods, the tutelar deities of light and shade, of cattle and of fruits- Apollo, Diana, Pan, and Ceres.
tgt_text.129: Prizes offered for such strains at these holy seasons would kindle a rivalry promotive of advancement, and render easier the steps by which they should pass into an art.
tgt_text.130: This is probably the key to the mythical ascription of pastoral poetry to Apollo Nomius, the herds­ man whilome in the halls of Admetus.
tgt_text.131: Diomus, Daphnis, and Stesiehorus, all of them Sicilian, may have been its first promoters upon Dorian soil;
tgt_text.132: and as Theocritus seems to have been the first who applied a highly cultivated mind to the task of infusing into Amæbœan strains the grace and beauty which he has wrought into his Idylls, his country Sicily stands justly foremost as the birth-place of Bucolic minstrelsy.
tgt_text.133: The Dorian character, too, was apter than that of other races to this kind of poetry:
tgt_text.134: mimetic art had its eminent representative in the Sicilian Sophron:
tgt_text.135: and among them mimetic and comic dia­ logue, as well as pastoral, arose in some measure out of the unstudied repartees of the Lydiastæ and Bucolistæ, or of some such performers.
tgt_text.136: These gave a basis, whereon the more studied Idyll might take its stand, and the great master of whom we are treating, was not slow to apply all his varied knowledge of nature and of art to this lively form of poetry, so calculated to keep the interest from flagging, the hearer or reader from becoming wearied.
tgt_text.137: He first moulded these rude strains into grace and beauty.
tgt_text.138: He smoothed the ruggednesses of verse.
tgt_text.139: He inspired the picture with novel life ;
tgt_text.140: and, whilst he preserved the guise of nature throughout, evinced that master power which is most teeming with the perfection of art, when its creations look likest nature.
tgt_text.141: It remains that we should attempt a classification of the various poems of Theocritus which have come down to us.
tgt_text.142: The arguments to each of these have been prefixed in the body of the translation.
tgt_text.143: Of the thirty Idylls extant, ten are properly Bucolics, the 1st, the 3rd, and all up to the 12th.
tgt_text.144: The 2nd Idyll can scarcely come under this head, though the wider term εἴδη, or εἰδύλλια, pictures, that is, of common every­ day life, may embrace that as well as the 14th, 15th, the 21st, and perhaps some others.
tgt_text.145: Some, however, claim the 2nd and 15th for a separate class under the head of mimetic Idylls.
tgt_text.148: the 22nd, 24th, 25th, and 26th, belong to the epic class ;
tgt_text.149: whilst the 28th is epistolary, and the 30th Anacreontic.

tgt_text.151: The genuineness of all the Idylls after the 18th has been much questioned :

tgt_text.153: They are for the most part in hexameter verse :

tgt_text.155: It is difficult to fix upon one beauty beyond another in these matchless pastorals, by singling out which one may send the uninitiated reader with a whetted appetite to the whole volume.
tgt_text.156: A thousand charms of poesy press forward, each claiming foremost commemoration.
tgt_text.157: In the first Idyll we linger long over the sorrows of Daphnis, which Virgil has transfused into his Eclogues, over the immortal lines (66— 69) which have lost none of their pristine sweetness, when, having passed the ordeal of transplantation, they bloom anew in the Lycidas of Milton, (Lycidas, 1. 50,) "
tgt_text.158: Where were ye, nymphs, when the remorseless deep," &c.;
tgt_text.159: or yet again in the same Idyll, over that (to the translator's taste at least) most enviable epitaph, (140, 141,) In the second Idyll, we view the fierceness of disappointed love, in the raging passion of Simætha :

tgt_text.161: Or if pretty picturings of scenery are more the object of our search, what translation can-do justice to the 13th Idyll, the Hylas, the charming rural scene in the end of the 7th, or the 25th Idyll from the 34th to the 50th line ?
tgt_text.162: There are passages in the Hylas unsurpassed by any poet of whatever age or clime ;

tgt_text.164: The Gossips of Theocritus are such a life-like picture, so capitally drawn, that it were a work of supererogation to point it out, or to commend it.
tgt_text.165: It is nature itself, not as it was seen in Sicily, or in Alexandria, but as it ever has been throughout the world.

tgt_text.178: Full many a rule of life he drew, Still pointing to the fair, the true, The youthful mind:
tgt_text.180: (Polwhele.)IF materials are scanty for a Life of Theocritus, they are much more so for those of his first imitators, Bion and Moschus.
tgt_text.181: An Elegy of the latter is the only faint glimmer of light, by which we can guess at, we cannot say discern, aught of history of the former.
tgt_text.182: Yet it would interest us if we could know how far Bion professedly reverenced Theocritus, what value he set upon simplicity in Pastorals, whether he aimed at a new school of that branch of the poetic art, and whether he would account as an improvement that over-refined sentiment­ ality which robs his Muse of all claim to be a child of nature.
tgt_text.183: But, except the 3rd Idyll of Moschus, no data for his life exist-unless we take upon the authority of Suidas that he was born beside that river, which by tradition is reputed to have reared on its banks the greatest of poets, the immortal Homer, the river Meles, at Phlossa in the neighbourhood of Smyrna.
tgt_text.184: From the Elegy above referred to, we assume that Bion left his native country for Sicily, and spent at least his latter days in cultivating the Bucolic minstrelsy, so thoroughly identified with that pastoral isle.
tgt_text.185: It seems hardly safe how­ ever to lay it down, with some, on the faith of the words in Moschus, (Id. iii. 17, &c.,) that Bion visited Thrace and Macedonia;
tgt_text.186: because the sense of the passage does not neces­ sarily imply more than that Strymonian swans and Æagrian nymphs might well mourn and weep afresh, since a Dorian, equal to their native Orpheus, had ceased to breathe forth his lovely lays.
tgt_text.187: One fact, however, stands out distinctly, namely, that the poet came to an untimely death by poison, which was administered to him by more than one individual, and that the murderers, whosoever they were, paid the penalty of their crime.
tgt_text.188: The age of Bion can be determined only by the statement of Moschus, (iii. 100—105,) that he was one of his disciples, and that Theocritus mourned his loss.
tgt_text.189: Grant - ing this, we must take his date as 280 B. C.
tgt_text.190: As has been before observed in the Life of Theocritus, the poems of Bion which have come down to us are vastly inferior in pastoral beauty, in natural simplicity, and inherent truthful­ ness, to the works of the Syracusan master.
tgt_text.191: But here and there we chance upon a passage of eminent loveliness.
tgt_text.192: Every where the Asiatic softness seems to add luxurious grace to his tuneful songs ;
tgt_text.193: though this is but a poor substitute for the vigorous and healthy freshness of the Father of Pastorals.

tgt_text.205: Still many passages might be quoted which are highly poetic, none more so perhaps than that exquisite passage in the third Idyll, (105—114,) where, in a lament over the briefness of this mor­ tal life, the mighty of the earth are contrasted with the flowers of the field in such an earnest tone of pathos, as shows the enlightened heathen dissatisfied with prevailing religions, whilst it teaches our own higher privileges, to us -who have, held out and within our grasp, " the sure and certain hope of the resurrection to eternal life.
tgt_text.206: "THE elegiac poet, Tyrtæus, whose remains, in an English garb, close the present volume, follows immediately in his branch of the poetic art, the founder -of Greek elegy, Callinus.
tgt_text.207: An elegy, according to the Greek notion, is a poem composed of a combination of hexameters and pentameters.
tgt_text.208: It seems often to have been of the nature of a dirge or lament, and the word ἔλεγος has no distinct reference to metrical form, though ἐλεγεία has.
tgt_text.210: Crossing the Ægean, it found one of its most eminent cultivators in Tyr­ tæus, the poet whom tradition has handed down to us as the Athenian present to their hereditary enemies the Spartans, when they had been directed by the Delphic oracle to seek a leader from Athens for the second Messenian war.
tgt_text.211: The story runs, that Athens, never hearty towards Sparta, save in her hatred, sent her the worst selection that, according to ap­ pearances, could be made,-a lame schoolmaster and composer of verses, who dwelt at Aphidnæ, a village of Attica :
tgt_text.212: and that this Ionian inspired the Dorian warriors who adopted him, with such spirit through his fiery strains, that victory crowned their prowess.
tgt_text.213: The second Messenian war is placed by Pausanias between 01. 23, 4 and 28, 1, that is, between B. c. 685 and 668:
tgt_text.214: but this date is considered by the latest authorities too high, and indeed, as Callinus probably flour­ ished about B. c. 660, and we are led to believe that Tyrtæus was but a few years junior to him, this would seem to be the more probable date.
tgt_text.215: The main features of the popular tradition, however pleas­ ing to our school-day notions of history, must of course be taken only as containing the germ of certain truths, and not as being themselves broad historical truths.
tgt_text.216: Castor and Pol­ lux, according to old legends, had been adopted by Aphidnus, the hero from whom Aphidnæ was named :
tgt_text.217: and as the Dios­ curi were Spartan, the Aphidnæans may have been moved by some feelings or ties of kindred, and not by the will of Athens, to send Tyrtæus to the aid of Laconia.
tgt_text.218: This would crush the fable of intentional insult on the part of Athens.
tgt_text.219: And then as to the origin of Tyrtæus, it cannot be doubted that he was of Ionian stock, (whether a native of Attica, or a settler in it from one of her Asiatic colonies, as Suidas states, it matters not, for the inventions of the colonies would soop find their way to their polished metropolis:
tgt_text.220: ) because we know that the branch of poetry in which he excelled was pe­ culiarly Ionian;
tgt_text.221: and not such as can claim any early vigour or native success among the Dorians.
tgt_text.222: Whether he came from Miletus to Aphidnæ, or was born at the latter place, we need not inquire ;

tgt_text.224: Surely his elegiac strains disprove this.
tgt_text.225: With regard to his lameness, and his supposed office of village school­ master at Aphidnæ, the truth to be evolved from these state­ ments is probably that he wrote uneven couplets, and, like other early poets, taught the art, of which he was so skilful a master.
tgt_text.226: If he was either by birth or by sojourn an Aphid­ naean, there is no wonder in his interest for Sparta, nor, on the other hand, any difficulty in understanding why, coining from Attica, he yet became a favourite with the Lacedæmonians.
tgt_text.228: And, certain it is, that whatever may have been his bodily defects, whatever his inexperience in generalship, his martial strains and wise counsels achieved much, in which a skilful general might have failed without them.

tgt_text.231: and when the foe was vanquish-The Poet, proposing to celebrate the end of Daphnis, the hero of Sicilian shepherds, finds an opening of his subject in a dialogue be­ tween a goatherd and a shepherd named Thyrsis.
tgt_text.232: The latter begs the former to sing with the accompaniment of his pipe.
tgt_text.233: This he de­ clines, for fear of awakening Pan, and strives to prevail upon Thyrsis, by the offer of a goat and a most highly wrought drinking-cup, to sing of the death of Daphnis.

tgt_text.358: Simaetha, a maid of Syracuse, of middle rank, (70—74,) seeing herself slighted by Delphis, of whom she is enamoured, becomes suspicious and jealous, and strives to regain his love by charms and philters.
tgt_text.359: At night, by the light of the moon, she holds a magic rite, to which chosen attendants are admitted.

tgt_text.554: Two hireling herdsmen chat together without any fixed subject of conversation.
tgt_text.555: The one, Corydon, is tending the herds of Ægon, who has become a wrestler and gone with Milo to the Olympic games.
tgt_text.556: The other, Bat­ tus, is a man of a sarcastic turn, and keeps annoying his fellow with various sharp sayings;
tgt_text.557: above all, predicting death to the ill-tended herds of Ægon.
tgt_text.558: Corydon, being easy and good-tempered, answers him mildly.
tgt_text.559: While they are chatting, the calves bark the straying olive branches, and Battus, driving them off, is pricked by a thorn.
tgt_text.560: While Corydon is tending his wound, they spy the old father of AEgon, and get into a smart talk about his wanton way of living.
tgt_text.561: This Idyll abounds in pictures of pastoral life and manners.
tgt_text.562: Its scene is laid in the country, at the foot of an olive-clad hill.
tgt_text.563: Virgil imitates it in his third Eclogue, together with the next Idyll.

tgt_text.673: and when they have disputed much about the prize for the victor, and the spot for the trial, they fetch one Morson, a woodcutter, for umpire.
tgt_text.674: They engage in an Amæbæan or alternate strain, in which, with no fixt subject, they wander through various topics,, supplied either by the condition of the singers, the nature of the country and spot, the memory of the past, or by their very anger and inclination.

tgt_text.832: Don't you remember when I beat you, and you, showing your teeth, 34 wriggled famously, and clung to yon oak ?
tgt_text.834: This indeed I do not recollect!
tgt_text.835: When however once upon a time Eumaras bound you here, and 35 dusted your jacket, that at all events I know very well.
tgt_text.837: At length, Morson, some one is growing angry :
tgt_text.838: Have you not slightly perceived it ?
tgt_text.839: Go and pluck old squills forthwith from the tomb.
tgt_text.841: I too, Morson, am vexing some one!
tgt_text.843: Go then to 36 the Hales, and dig up the sow­ bread.
tgt_text.845: May the 37 Himera flow with milk instead of water !
tgt_text.846: and mayest thou too, Crathis, grow purple with wine ! 38 and may the yellow-water cresses, look you, bear fruit!
tgt_text.848: And for my sake may the fountain of Sybaris flow with honey !
tgt_text.849: and, towards dawn, may the maiden in her pitcher 39 draw combs instead of water !
tgt_text.851: My goats indeed eat hadder and ægilus, and tread on mastich-twigs, and lie among arbute-trees !
tgt_text.853: But my sheep have at hand baulm to browse, and the wild eglantine, too, blooms in abundance, like roses.
tgt_text.855: I love not Alcippe, for but lately she did not kiss me, having caught me 40 by the ears ;
tgt_text.856: what time I gave her the ring-dove.
tgt_text.859: for when I held out the pipe to him, he kissed me in a very sweet manner.
tgt_text.861: 'Tis not right, Lacon, that jays should contend with a nightingale, or 41 hoopoes with the swans :
tgt_text.862: but you, wretch­ ed man, are prone to strife.
tgt_text.865: And to thee, Comatas, Morson presents the lamb :
tgt_text.866: and so do you sacrifice to the Nymphs, and presently send a fine portion of meat to Morson.
tgt_text.868: I will send it, yes, by Pan.
tgt_text.869: Wanton now, all my herd of he-goats !
tgt_text.870: For see how great is the laugh that I also shall raise against this Lacon the shepherd, 42 because at last I have gained the lamb :
tgt_text.871: I will leap for you to heaven.
tgt_text.872: Be of good cheer, my horned she-goats:
tgt_text.873: 41 to-morrow I will wash you all in the fountain of Sybaris.
tgt_text.874: You, sir, the white goat, 44 that butt-with-the-horn, if you molest any of the she goats, I will beat you, yes, before I sacrifice the ewe-lamb to the Nymphs.
tgt_text.875: Yet he is at it again.
tgt_text.876: Well, may I become 45 Melan­ thius, instead of Comatas, if I don't beat you.
tgt_text.877: Damætas and Daphnis, having driven their herds to water, while away the time in Amæbæan strains.
tgt_text.878: The youths picture Polyphemus seated on a rock overlooking the sea;
tgt_text.879: and Galatea, his love, on the other hand, sporting in the waves at no great distance from the shore.
tgt_text.880: Daphnis begins, directing his song to the Cyclops :
tgt_text.881: and Damætas responds un­ der the character of Polyphemus.
tgt_text.882: The performance is ended by mu­ tual presents between the swains.
tgt_text.883: The Idyll is commended by the manner in which the character and temper of the Cyclops is shadowed forth.
tgt_text.884: Its subject is the same as that of Idyll xi.
tgt_text.885: Compare also Moschus, Idyll iii. 59—63.DAMÆTAS and Daphnis, the herdsman, once drove the herd to one spot, 1 0 Aratus :
tgt_text.886: now one of them was reddish in beard, and the other had but half a one:
tgt_text.887: and both of them, taking their seats at a certain fountain, in summer-time at mid-day, began to sing as follows.
tgt_text.888: And Daphnis struck up first, since he too was first to challenge.
tgt_text.889: Daphnis. 2 Galatea, 0 Polyphemus, pelts your flock with apples, calling you the goat-herd inaccessible-to-love :
tgt_text.890: and you do not regard her, wretched, wretched man, but sit play­ ing sweetly on your pipe.
tgt_text.891: See again, she is pelting the bitch, which follows you as sheep-watch:
tgt_text.892: but it is barking, looking toward the sea ;
tgt_text.893: and the fair waves, as they gently plash, 3 show it running on the shore.
tgt_text.894: Take care, lest it rush against the legs of the damsel, as she comes forth from the brine, and tear her beauteous flesh.
tgt_text.895: Yet she, even on the spur of the moment, coquets, like the dried down from a thistle, when the fine summer parches :
tgt_text.896: and 4 she flies you, if you love her, and if you love her not, pursues you ;
tgt_text.897: and 5 moves the stone from the line :
tgt_text.898: for surely, Polyphemus, oft­ times to love what is not fair, seems fair.
tgt_text.899: And after him Damætas struck up to sing sweetly.
tgt_text.901: I saw her, yes, by Pan, when she was pelting my.
tgt_text.902: flock, and she escaped not my notice, no, by my one sweet eye, with which I look till the end of my days;
tgt_text.903: 6 but may the pro­ phet, Telemus, declaring hostile things, 7 carry off to his home what is hostile, that he may lay it up for his children.
tgt_text.904: However, I myself too, attempting to vex her, do not regard her in turn;
tgt_text.905: but say, that some other woman possesses me:
tgt_text.906: and she, when she hears it, is jealous of me, 0 Pæan, and pines away:
tgt_text.907: 8 and she runs wild, peering forth from the sea toward my caves, and toward my flocks.
tgt_text.908: And I bade my dog bark at her :
tgt_text.909: for when I was enamoured of her, it used to whine, keeping its nose to her hips.
tgt_text.910: Now perhaps when she sees me doing this frequently, she will send a messenger.
tgt_text.911: But I shall shut my doors, until she shall have sworn that she will herself strew for me a beautiful couch 9 on this island.
tgt_text.912: For 10in truth neither have I so ugly a form as they say I have.
tgt_text.913: For surely but lately I was looking into the sea (and it was a calm) :
tgt_text.914: and beautiful indeed my beard, and beautiful my solitary eyeball, (as it has been determined by my judg­ ment,) appeared ;
tgt_text.915: 11 and it reflected a brightness of teeth, whiter than Parian marble.
tgt_text.916: And that I might not be be­ witched, 12 I spat thrice upon my breast:
tgt_text.917: for thus the old woman 13 Cotyttaris instructed me to do, who of late used to sing to the reapers in the fields of Hippocoon.
tgt_text.918: Having sung thus much, Damætas kissed Daphnis ;
tgt_text.919: and the latter gave the former a pipe, and he a beautiful flute to the latter.
tgt_text.920: Damætas was playing the flute, and the herdsman Daphnis the pipes.
tgt_text.921: Forthwith the calves were leaping on soft herbage.
tgt_text.922: However neither one conquered, but they were unsurpassed.
tgt_text.923: in this Idyll, one Simichidas is represented describing a celebration of the festival in honour of De meter after harvest, in which he himself and some friends had been engaged at the house of Phrasidamus and Antigenes, on the banks of the Hales.
tgt_text.924: The former part of the Idyll is a narration of the journey to the feast;
tgt_text.925: the latter, a description of the feast itself.
tgt_text.926: On their road, Simichidas and his friends fall in with a goatherd, Lycidas, of great poetic talent, whom they invite to while the length of the way by his song.
tgt_text.927: He accordingly sings, his love for the boy Ageanax.
tgt_text.928: After which, Simichidas in turn celebrates the pas­ sion of Aratus for the lad Philinus.
tgt_text.929: The songs being ended, Lycidas presents Simichidas with a crook, and turns off on another route.
tgt_text.930: The rest go forward to their proposed destination, where beside the mur­ inuring fountain, in a most delightful spot, they indulge in wine and good cheer.
tgt_text.931: The scene, according to the Scholiast, is laid in Cos ;
tgt_text.932: though Heinsius maintains that Sicily is represented.
tgt_text.933: Theocritus is known to have stayed some time at Cos to hear Philetas, which makes for the Scholiast's view.
tgt_text.934: It has been supposed that the poet describes himself under the character of Simichidas, and a Cydonian poet of his own day under the name of Lycidas.
tgt_text.935: Virgil has planned his ninth Eclogue somewhat on the model of this Idyll.1 IT was the time when I and Eucritus were sauntering from the city to the Hales, and with us a third, Amyntas.
tgt_text.936: For to Ceres both Thrasidamus and Antigenes, two sons of Lycopeus, were preparing the Thalysia;
tgt_text.937: worthy men, if aught is worthy that springs from the good men of old, being descended both from 2 Clytia and Chalcon himself;
tgt_text.938: 3 he who by his foot raised the fountain Burinna, having planted strongly his knee against the rock :
tgt_text.939: and beside it, 4the poplars and elms were yielding a grove of shade, 5 overhanging, as they waved, with green foliage.
tgt_text.941: Nor yet had we finished half our way, nor did the tomb of Brasilas yet come in sight to us, when we fell in with a wayfarer, 7 a favourite with the Muses, a man of Cydon, whose name was Lycidas ;
tgt_text.942: he was a goatherd, nor could any one that looked upon him have mistaken him, for he was exceedingly like a goatherd.
tgt_text.943: For on his shoulders he wore a 8 tawny skin of a shaggy thick-haired goat, smelling of new rennet:
tgt_text.944: an old cloak was fastened by a broad belt about his breast;
tgt_text.945: whilst in his right hand he held a crooked club of wild-olive :
tgt_text.946: and grinning, he said to me softly with a smiling eye (and laughter played upon his lip) :
tgt_text.947: 9 ‘Simichidas, where, prythee, art thou dragging thy steps at mid-day?
tgt_text.948: when in sooth even 10the green lizard sleeps on the fences, and the crested larks roam not abroad ?
tgt_text.949: Art invited and hastening to a banquet ?
tgt_text.950: or art for storming the wine-vats of some cit ?
tgt_text.951: since as thou footest it along, every stone rings, as it strikes against 11 thy half-boots.'
tgt_text.952: Then I answered him, 'Friend Lycidas, all say you are a piper greatly distinguished both among herdsmen and among reapers:
tgt_text.953: which in truth vastly delights my mind ;
tgt_text.954: yet in my fancy, I hope to rival you.
tgt_text.955: Now this is our way to the 12 Thalysia :
tgt_text.956: for our friends in sooth are making a feast to Demeter of the beautiful robe, offering the first-fruits of their abundance :
tgt_text.957: since for them, in very bounteous measure, the goddess hath piled the threshing-floor 13 with barley.
tgt_text.958: But come now, (for our road is in common, and the day is alike ours,) let us sing pas­ torals ;
tgt_text.959: perhaps the one will gratify the other.
tgt_text.960: For I 14 too am a clear voice of the Muses, and all men call me an ex­ cellent minstrel;
tgt_text.961: but I am one not of easy persuasion.
tgt_text.964: for not yet, to my own fancy, do I. surpass in singing either the good 15 Sicelidas from Samos, or Philetas, but strive with them, like a frog among locusts.
tgt_text.967: but the goatherd smiling plea­ santly, ‘I give you this 16 club,' quoth he, ‘ because you are a scion of Jove, fashioned altogether for sincerity.
tgt_text.968: 17 For as the architect is odious to me, who attempts to build a house equal to the top of Mount 18Oromedon, so are birds of the Muses, as many as, crowing against the Cbian minstrel, toil to no purpose.
tgt_text.969: But come, let us commence at once the pastoral strain, Simichidas :
tgt_text.970: as I will-see now, friend, if this ditty, which I erst finished off on the mountain, suits your taste.
tgt_text.971: '‘Ageanax shall have a fair voyage to Mitylene, when the south wind chases the moist waves 19 in the season of the Kids at-their-setting, and when 20 Orion rests his feet on the ocean, if haply he shall have rescued Lycidas scorched by Aphro­ dite :
tgt_text.972: for ardent love of him consumes me.
tgt_text.973: And halcyons shall 21 smooth the waves, and the sea, and the south-west wind, and the south-east, which stirs the remotest seaweeds:
tgt_text.974: hal­ cyons, which have been beloved most of birds, whose prey is on the sea, by the green Nereids.
tgt_text.975: May all things be season­ able to Ageanax, seeking a fair wind for Mitylene:
tgt_text.976: and may he reach the harbour after a favourable voyage.
tgt_text.977: 22 And I, on that day, crowning my head with a chaplet of dill, or of roses, or even of white 23 violets, will drain from the bowl the 24Pte­ leatic wine, as I recline beside the fire :
tgt_text.978: and one shall roast me a bean in the flame, and the bed of leaves shall be covered- thickly elbow-deep with flea-bane, and asphodel and curling parsley.
tgt_text.979: 25 Then freely will I drink, in memory of Ageanax, pressing my lip to the very cup even to the dregs.
tgt_text.980: 26 And there shall pipe for me two shepherds, one an Acharnian, and one from Lycope:
tgt_text.981: and near them Tityrus shall sing, how once the herdsman Daphnis loved the foreign maid, and how he traversed the mountain, and how the oaks bewailed him which grow beside the banks of the river 27 Himeras :
tgt_text.982: when he wasted away, as any snow on lofty Hæmus, or Athos, or Rhodope, or remotest Caucasus :
tgt_text.983: he shall sing too how once a wide chest received the goatherd yet living, 28 through the baneful vio­ lence of his master;
tgt_text.984: and how the flat-nosed bees coming from the meadows to the sweet cedar, were wont to feed him on soft flowers, because the Muses had poured down his throat pleasant nectar.
tgt_text.985: 0 fortunate Comatas, thou in sooth hast experienced these delights, and thou hast been enclosed in a chest, and thou, being fed on the combs of bees, 29hast com­ pleted the spring of the year.
tgt_text.986: 30 Would that in my day thou hadst been numbered among the living, since I would then have tended for thee thy beautiful she-goats, along the mountains, while listening to thy voice :
tgt_text.987: and thou, divine Comatas, shouldst have reclined under the oaks or under the pines, sweetly singing.
tgt_text.989: And Lycidas having sung thus much, made an end :
tgt_text.990: but to him in turn I also spoke as follows:
tgt_text.991: ‘Many other good things, friend Lycidas, have the Nymphs taught me too, as I tend my herd along the mountains:
tgt_text.992: things which 31 haply fame hath carried even to the throne of Jove.
tgt_text.993: But this at any rate is far pre-eminent beyond all, with which I will proceed to favour you.
tgt_text.994: Hearken then, since you are a friend to the Muses.'32'
tgt_text.995: On Simichidas indeed the Loves have sneezed:
tgt_text.996: for of a truth the luckless wight is as much in love with Myrto, as the she-goats love spring.
tgt_text.997: But Aratus, who is in the highest degree beloved by that man, cherishes at heart a yearning for a lad.
tgt_text.998: 33 Aristis, a worthy man, and highly excellent, (whose singing with the accompaniment of the lyre not even Phœbus himself beside his tripods would refuse,) knows that by a lad Aratus,is consumed to the very bone with love.
tgt_text.999: Him I pray thee, 0 Pan, who hast obtained for thy portion the lovely surface of 34 Homole, mayest thou place unbidden in the dear hands of that man, whether it is in sooth the tender Philinus, or some other. !
tgt_text.1000: And -if indeed thou shouldst do thus, 0 dear PaD, then may 35 Arcadian boys in no wise scourge thee with squills on ribs and shoulders, at such times as scanty feasts are provided:
tgt_text.1001: but shouldst thou have decided otherwise, mayest thou be scratched all over thy flesh by the nails, and mayest thou sleep among nettles:
tgt_text.1002: and in mid-winter mayest thou be on the 36mountains of the Edonians, beside the river Hebrus, facing towards and nigh to the north ;
tgt_text.1003: and in summer mayest thou tend herds among the extremest Æthi­ opians, 37 under the rock of the Blemyes, whence the Nile is no longer to be seen.
tgt_text.1004: But do ye, having left the sweet water of 38 Hyetis and Byblis, and dwelling in the lofty 39 seat of golden-haired Dione, 40 0 Loves like unto ruddy apples, strike, I pray you, with your arrows, the lovely Philinus :
tgt_text.1005: strike, for the wretched youth pities not my guest.
tgt_text.1006: And yet he is more over-ripe than a pear, and the women say, Alas, alas, Philinus, thy beauty's bloom wastes away.
tgt_text.1007: No longer, look you, Aratus, let us keep watch at the vestibules, nor wear out our feet, but let the early cock consign 41 another, as he crows, to this painful numbness :
tgt_text.1008: and let Molon alone, my best of friends, be harassed in this sharp exercise:
tgt_text.1009: and to us let both quietness be a care, and an old woman be at hand, who, 42 by spitting, may keep afar off what is not good.
tgt_text.1012: and he, having smiled sweetly, as before, presented me with his crook to be a friendly gift 43arising out of our songs.
tgt_text.1013: And he indeed, having turned off to the left, proceeded on his way to Pyxa:
tgt_text.1014: but I and Eucritus, having bent our steps to the house of Phrasidamus, with the beautiful 44 Amyntichus, reclined there, both.
tgt_text.1015: on deep low­ couches of the sweet mastich-tree, and on fresh-cut vine-twigs, rejoicingly.
tgt_text.1016: And, from above, down upon our heads were waving to and fro many poplars and elms ;
tgt_text.1017: and the sacred stream hard by kept murmuring, as it flowed down from the cave of the Nymphs.
tgt_text.1018: And the fire-coloured cicalas on the shady branches were toiling at chirping;
tgt_text.1019: while, from afar off, in the thick thorn-bushes the thrush was warbling.
tgt_text.1020: Tufted larks and 45 gold-finches were singing ;
tgt_text.1022: 46 tawny bees were humming round about the foun­ tains :
tgt_text.1023: all things were breathing-the-incense of very plenteous summer, and breathing-the-incense of fruit-time.
tgt_text.1024: 47 Pears indeed at our feet, and by our sides apples, were rolling for us in abundance ;
tgt_text.1025: and the boughs hung-in-profusion, weighed down to the ground, with damsons.
tgt_text.1026: 48 Moreover the pitch of four years' date was loosened from the mouth of the wine jars.
tgt_text.1027: Ye Castalian Nymphs, inhabiting the height of Parnassus, I wonder whether 49 at all in the rocky cave of Pholus, aged Chiron set up for Hercules a goblet such as this !
tgt_text.1028: I wonder if haply 'twas nectar like this, which induced that shepherd by the Anapus, the strong Polyphemus, who 50 used to hurl crags on the mountain-ranges, to dance about in the sheep­ pens ?
tgt_text.1029: Such nectar I mean, as, 0 Nymphs, ye then broached, beside the altar of Demeter presiding over the threshing-floor:
tgt_text.1030: on the heap of which may I again fasten a great winnowing shovel, and may she smile, holding in both hands 51 wheat sheaves and poppies.
tgt_text.1031: In this Idyll two pastors are represented as contending, Daphnis and Menalcas, both skilled in music and in Amæbæan song.
tgt_text.1032: A challenge is given, and a prize set up, and a goatherd called in as umpire.
tgt_text.1033: They begin the song, so as to answer one another first with four, afterwards with eight verses each.
tgt_text.1034: At last the goatherd adjudges the prize to Daphnis—and the poet represents this victory as laying the foundation of all the future fame of Daphnis, in pastoral poetry.
tgt_text.1035: The scene is laid in Sicily.
tgt_text.1036: Virgil has copied this Idyll much in Eclogues iii.
tgt_text.1038: MENALCAS, 1as they say, whilst tending his sheep along the high mountains, fell in with the graceful Daphnis a-driving his herd.
tgt_text.1040: Now both of them were 3 red-haired, both lads :
tgt_text.1041: each skilled in playing on the pipes, each in singing.
tgt_text.1042: And first then Menalcas, gazing at Daphnis, addressed him.
tgt_text.1044: Daphnis, watcher of the lowing oxen, wilt thou sing with me ?
tgt_text.1045: I maintain that I will beat you at singing, to my heart's content.
tgt_text.1046: And him, I ween, Daphnis answered in speech like the following.
tgt_text.1048: Shepherd of woolly sheep, piper Menalcas, you at all events shall never beat me in singing, no, not if you should die for it.
tgt_text.1050: Are you desirous then to see into it ?
tgt_text.1051: Are you desirous to stake a prize ?
tgt_text.1053: I do desire to see into this.
tgt_text.1054: I am desirous to stake a prize.
tgt_text.1056: Well what shall we stake, that would be of sufficient value for us ?
tgt_text.1059: and do you stake on your part 5 a lamb like its mother.
tgt_text.1061: 6I will never stake a lamb, for both ray father is strict, and my mother, and they count all the sheep at evening.
tgt_text.1063: Well then, what will you stake ?
tgt_text.1064: And what shall be the advantage the winner shall have ?
tgt_text.1066: A shepherd's-pipe, which I made beautiful with nine notes, and having white wax about it, equal below, equal above.
tgt_text.1068: but my father's property I will not stake.
tgt_text.1070: In truth I too, look you, have a pipe with nine notes, haying white wax about it, equal below, equal above.
tgt_text.1072: Even still I have a pain in this finger, since the reed, i'fegs, split and cut me.
tgt_text.1076: How if we should call hither yon goatherd, whose dog 8 with-the-white-spot, is barking near the kids.
tgt_text.1077: And the youths indeed shouted to him, and the goatherd came, having heard them.
tgt_text.1078: And the youths on their part be­ gan to sing, and the goatherd was willing to be umpire.
tgt_text.1079: So then first the 9 piper Menalcas proceeded to sing, having ob­ tained precedence by lot.
tgt_text.1080: And then Daphnis took up the alternate pastoral strain.
tgt_text.1083: Ye dells and rivers, 10a divine progeny, if haply ever the piper Menalcas has sung a pleasant melody, may ye feed my lambkins 11to my heart's content:
tgt_text.1084: and should Daphnis ever chance to have come with his calves, may he find nothing less.
tgt_text.1086: Ye springs, and herbage, a pleasant growth, if so be that Daphnis warbles like the nightingales, fatten ye this herd!
tgt_text.1087: And if Menalcas shall have driven any stock hither, may he, to his satisfaction, pasture all in plenty.
tgt_text.1089: Every where it is spring, and every where are pas­ tures :
tgt_text.1090: and every where udders are full of milk, and the young are suckled, where the fair maiden approaches:
tgt_text.1091: but if she should depart, both the shepherd is withered there, and the herbage too.
tgt_text.1093: Sheep are there, she-goats with twins are there, bees fill their hives there, and the oaks are loftier, wherever the handsome Milo sets foot;
tgt_text.1094: 13 but should he depart, both he who feeds the heifers, and the heifers themselves, are the more dried up.
tgt_text.1095: Men. 0 he-goat, husband of the white she-goats !
tgt_text.1096: 14 where there is endless depth of foliage, 0 ye flat-nosed kids, come hither to the water.
tgt_text.1097: For in that place is he!
tgt_text.1098: Go, stump-horn, and say to Milo, that 15 Proteus, even though a god, used to feed sea-calves.
tgt_text.1100: Not mine be it to possess the land of Pelops, nor mine to own golden talents, or to outstrip the winds:
tgt_text.1101: but I will sing under this rock, holding thee in my arms, 16looking upon my sheep feeding together, and towards the Sicilian sea.
tgt_text.1103: To trees indeed winter is a dreadful evil, and to waters drought, and to birds the snare, and to wild beasts nets:
tgt_text.1104: but to man the yearning for a tender maiden.
tgt_text.1105: 0 Sire, O Jove, not I alone have been in love.
tgt_text.1106: 17 Thou too art a lover of women.
tgt_text.1107: 'These strains indeed then the youths sang alternately:
tgt_text.1108: and Menalcas thus commenced his concluding song.
tgt_text.1110: Spare my kids, spare, wolf, my she-goats with young, and do not hurt me, because, small though I am, I tend many.
tgt_text.1111: 18 0 dog Lampurus, does so deep a sleep hold you ?
tgt_text.1112: You ought not to sleep soundly while tending sheep with a lad.
tgt_text.1113: And, ye sheep, neither do you shrink from filling yourselves with the tender herbage.
tgt_text.1114: Ye shall be nowise tired of it, when this springs up again.
tgt_text.1115: St! feed on, feed on, and, all of you, fill your udders, that the lambs may have a part, and I may lay up the rest in cheese baskets.
tgt_text.1116: Next in turn, Daphnis struck up to sing sweetly.
tgt_text.1117: Daph. 19 Me too, a maiden with meeting eye-brows, having seen yesterday from her cave, as I drove past it my heifers, kept declaring to be beautiful, beautiful.
tgt_text.1118: Nor indeed did I even answer her a rude word, but kept trudging on my way, looking downwards.
tgt_text.1119: 20 Sweet is the voice of the heifer, sweet the breath of the pipe;
tgt_text.1120: and sweetly too the calf lows, and sweetly also the cow:
tgt_text.1121: and sweet is it 21 in summer-time to sleep in the open air beside running water.
tgt_text.1122: 22 The acorns are an ornament to the oak, apples to the apple-tree, and to the cows the calf, the cows themselves to the herdsman.
tgt_text.1123: Thus sang the youths, but the goatherd addressed them as follows:
tgt_text.1125: Something sweet is thy mouth, and lovely thy voice, 0 Daphnis.
tgt_text.1126: 'Tis better to hear thee sing than 23to sip honey.
tgt_text.1127: Take the pipe, for thou hast won in singing.
tgt_text.1128: And if at all you desire to teach me too to sing, while I feed my goats along with you, I will give you, as the price of your teaching, yon hornless she-goat, which always fills the milk- pail above the brim.
tgt_text.1129: As then the youth was delighted, and leapt up, and shouted as victorious;
tgt_text.1130: so would a fawn leap upon its dam.
tgt_text.1131: And as the other smouldered away, and was cast down in heart by chagrin, so also would a nymph grieve, 24when betrothed.
tgt_text.1132: And from this time, Daphnis became first among shepherds, and, while yet in earliest youth, wedded a Naiad nymph.
tgt_text.1133: The scene is laid in Sicily.
tgt_text.1134: Daphnis and Menaleas are challenged by a companion shepherd to contend with one another in singing.
tgt_text.1135: They sing in alternate strains, and each carries off a prize;
tgt_text.1136: Daphnis a crook, and Menalcas a muscle-shell.
tgt_text.1137: It seems clear that the whole Idyll is put in the mouth of a shepherd, who narrates the alternate strains of Daphnis and Menalcas, just as Melibæus (Virg. Ecl. vii.) those of Corydon and Thyrsis.
tgt_text.1138: Warton observes that Menalcas in his song assumes the character of the Cyclops.
tgt_text.1139: SING a pastoral strain, Daphnis, and do you first begin the song;
tgt_text.1140: begin you the 1 song, first, and let Menalcas follow after, when you have put the calves to the heifers, and the bulls to the barren cows.
tgt_text.1141: And let them feed together, and stray among the foliage, 2not at all forsaking the herd :
tgt_text.1142: but do you sing me a bucolic strain in the first place ;
tgt_text.1143: and in the next, in turn let Menalcas answer.
tgt_text.1145: Sweetly indeed the calf lows, and sweetly too does the heifer;
tgt_text.1146: and sweetly also the pipe sounds, and the herdsman, and sweetly I too.
tgt_text.1147: And by the cool water-side I have a couch of leaves;
tgt_text.1148: and on it have been strown beautiful skins from white heifers, all of which, to my sorrow, as they nibbled the 3arbute-tree, the south-west wind dashed from the mountain peak.
tgt_text.1149: And I care as much for the parching summer 4as lovers care to hear the words of a father or mother.
tgt_text.1153: Ætna is my mother, and I inhabit a fair cave in the hollow rocks:
tgt_text.1154: and I have in sooth whatever things appear in a dream, 5many sheep and many goats ;
tgt_text.1155: of which the skins lie at my head, and beside my feet.
tgt_text.1156: And on a fire of oak­ boughs entrails are boiling, and on the fire are dry beech- fagots when it is winter ;
tgt_text.1157: and in truth not even have I a care for winter, as much as a toothless person has for nuts, when 6fine meal is at hand.

tgt_text.1168: for whomso­ ever they behold with pleasure, such hath 13 Circe never at all hurt with her draught.
tgt_text.1169: In this Idyll, which is strictly pastoral, Milo and Battus, two reapers, converse over their work.
tgt_text.1170: Now Battus, being enamoured of a female flute-player, Bombyce, the daughter of Polybutas, or as some suppose his handmaiden, works but slackly in consequence.
tgt_text.1171: Whereupon Milo asks him why he reaps so lazily, and Battus confesses to him his love;
tgt_text.1172: and recites a ditty composed for his mistress.
tgt_text.1173: Milo then opposes to this song, another of his own, containing precepts on the art of reaping, having first applauded Battus for the fitness and beauty of his composition.
tgt_text.1174: You labouring ploughman, what has befallen you now, wretched man ?
tgt_text.1175: Neither can you 1draw the swathe straight, as of old you used to draw it;
tgt_text.1176: nor do you reap in a line with your neighbour, but are left behind, as a sheep, whose foot a thorn has wounded, is left by the flock.
tgt_text.1177: A fine sort of reaper you will be, won't you, at evening, and after mid-day, seeing that now, when you begin, 2 you do not make a gap in the swathe ?
tgt_text.1179: Milo, you who reap till late at even, fragment of stubborn rock, did it never befall you to long after one of the absent ?
tgt_text.1182: And what business has a labouring man with longing after those that are without ?
tgt_text.1184: Did it never then chance to you to lie awake through love ?
tgt_text.1186: No, and I trust it never may.

tgt_text.1248: This Idyll commences with a preface to Nicias, a physician of Miletus, (to whom Theocritus inscribes the 13th Idyll, and of whom he makes favourable mention in Idyll xxviii. 6, and Epigr. vii. 3,) respecting the power of song in relieving the pains of disappointed love.
tgt_text.1249: The Cyclops is represented as using this solace for his hopeless passion for Galatea.
tgt_text.1250: Polyphemus, sitting on a rock overhanging the sea, beguiles his hours with song.
tgt_text.1251: He accuses the fair one of pride, and scorn for his deep devotion to her;
tgt_text.1252: and boasts of the gifts of fortune, which he can show, in lieu of gifts of beauty and personal grace.
tgt_text.1253: At last he seems to recover from his infatuation, perceiving the vanity of his hopes.
tgt_text.1254: Virgil has had this Idyll in his eye, while writing Eclogues ii.
tgt_text.1256: and Bion perhaps gathered from it some ideas for the first part of his 15th Idyll.
tgt_text.1257: Compare Ovid Met. xiii. 755, &c., and Callimach. Epigr. xlix. p. 316 (Ernesti).1 THERE is no other remedy for love, 0 Nicias, either 2 in the way of salve, as it seems to me, or of plaster, except the Muses :
tgt_text.1258: but this is a light and sweet thing amongst men, yet 'tis not easy to find.
tgt_text.1259: But methinks you know it well, as being a physician, and in truth a man especially beloved by the nine Muses.
tgt_text.1260: Thus, for instance, the famous Cyclops our countryman, the ancient Polyphemus, used most easily to pass his time, when he was enamoured of Galatea, just as he was now getting a beard about his mouth and temples.
tgt_text.1261: And he was wont to love,­ not at all with roses, or apples, or locks of hair, but with un­ done fury:
tgt_text.1262: and he held all things secondary to his fury.
tgt_text.1264: Oft­ times his sheep went back by themselves to the fold from the green herbage ;
tgt_text.1266: Galatea, pined away' there, on the sea-weedy shore, from break of day, having beneath his breast a most hateful wound inflicted by mighty Venus, 4since she had fastened an arrow in his heart.
tgt_text.1268: But he found his remedy, and sitting upon a high rock, looking to­ wards the sea, he was wont to sing such strains as this.'0 fair Galatea, why dost thou spurn thy lover?
tgt_text.1269: 6More white than cream-cheese to look upon, more tender than a lamb, more frisky than a calf, more sleek than an unripe grape ?

tgt_text.1289: there is cool water, which wooded Ætna sends forth for me, a diving drink, out of white snow:
tgt_text.1290: (who would prefer to these delights to dwell in sea or waves ?)

tgt_text.1310: This Idyll, which is of a lyric, not a Bucolic character, has been suspect­ ed to be not the work of Theocritus.
tgt_text.1311: It is an expression of love towards a youth on his return to his friend after three days' absence.
tgt_text.1312: The poet goes on to hope that this love may be mutual and perpetual.
tgt_text.1313: It is ended with a strain in honour of the Megarensians, on account of their having instituted annual kissing-matches at the tomb of Dio­ cles.

tgt_text.1339: The poet premising somewhat about the power of love over gods and men, opens the subject of the rape of Hylas with a description of the love and care of Hercules for the lad.
tgt_text.1340: When the Argonauts had put to shore at the land of the Cyanians, on the coast of the Propontis, Hylas was sent by Hercules to fetch water.
tgt_text.1341: Whilst drawing from the fountain, in a lovely spot, he is drawn in by the Nymphs, who are captivated by the exceeding beauty of the boy.
tgt_text.1342: Hercules, suspecting some mishap from the delay of Hylas, sets out in quest of him ;
tgt_text.1343: and as his fruitless search detains him a long time, he is left behind by the Argonauts, who suppose he has quitted them purposely.
tgt_text.1344: The hero goes afoot to Colchis.
tgt_text.1345: This Idyll is Epic in its character, but with such a touch of Bucolic sweetness about it as to win it a high place among the Idylls of Theocritus.
tgt_text.1346: Note the description of the fountain, vs. 40, and the anxiety of the Nymphs to console the lad, 54—59.NOT for us alone, as we used to suppose, my Nicias, did he beget Eros, to 1 whomsoever of the gods this child was once born:

tgt_text.1349: and he was never apart from him, not even if mid-day were rising, nor when the white-horsed chariot of Aurora was mounting to the halls of Jove, nor when the chirping young birds looked to their nest, their mother having fluttered her wings upon her dusky perch:

tgt_text.1753: The poet intending to celebrate Ptolemy Philadelphus, king of Egypt, sets out with the praise of his father, Ptolemy Lagus, to whom after his death a place among the gods had been ascribed ;
tgt_text.1754: and goes on to eulogize Berenice, the mother of Philadelphus, whom Venus was sup­ posed to have received into her temples to be her πάρεδρος, or assessor, He next proceeds to set forth the fortunes and virtues of Philadelphus himself, beginning with the happy omens which had attended his birth in the island of Cos, and portended his future opulence and power.
tgt_text.1755: Then follows an enumeration of the royal territories, and laudation of the royal wealth, augmented as it has been by the blessings of peace.
tgt_text.1756: The poet commends in glowing terms the munificence and discern­ ment of Philadelphus in conferring favours, as well as his filial piety shown so eminently.
tgt_text.1757: He ends with praise of the queen, the wife and sister of Ptolemy.

tgt_text.1935: This Idyll contains a conversation of two fishermen by night.
tgt_text.1936: Our poet addressing one Diophantus with a few observations on the force of poverty in rousing men to active pursuits, describes the scene of this colloquy, which is laid in a scantily furnished sea-side but.

tgt_text.1941: His comrade bids him be of good cheer, telling him that his oath is clearly no more real than his dream was.

tgt_text.2001: This hymn to the Dioscuri is divided into two parts-the first (27—134) in praise of Pollux, the second of Castor.
tgt_text.2002: After a proem (1—26) sounding their common praises, a most renowned contest between Pollux and Amycus is described.

tgt_text.2004: who gives out to them that they shall then only draw water, when they ':
tgt_text.2006: Terms are accepted, the Argonauts and Bebrycians convened, and in the conflict Pollux comes off victorious, although there was reason to fear that his adversary's vast strength might overwhelm him.
tgt_text.2007: In the remainder of the Hymn is commemorated Castor's fight with Lynceus.
tgt_text.2008: The cir­ cumstances of which were these.
tgt_text.2009: When the Dioscuri had carried off the daughters of Leucippus, Idas and Lynceus, the sons of Aphareus, their betrothed lovers, overtake the ravishers at the tomb of Aphareus.
tgt_text.2010: Then Lynceus having in vain tried to persuade the Dioscuri to give back the maidens, challenges Castor to single combat.
tgt_text.2011: Castor accepts the challenge, and they fight first with spears, and then with swords, till Lynceus is wounded, and pierced through at his father's tomb, to which he had fled.
tgt_text.2012: Idas, grieved at the loss of his brother, seizes a fragment of the tomb to hurl at Castor, but is himself overthrown in the act by a thunderbolt from Jupiter.
